greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of pairs of primes (p,q), p < q, which are a solution of the Diophantine equation (p-1)*(q-1) = (2n)^2.
comment: a(n) is also the number of semiprimes p*q whose totient is a square (A247129) and equal to (2*n)^2.
From _Robert G. Wilson v_, Mar 30 2019, Mar 30 2019: (Start)
If n is a prime <> 3, then a(n) = 1 if n is in A052291 and 0 otherwise, and a(n^2) = 1 if 2*n+1 and 2*n^3+1 are primes and 0 otherwise. - _Robert Israel_, Apr 04 2019
link: Robert Israel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: a(11) = 0  because (2*11)^2 can't be written as (p-1)*(q-1) with p < q.
maple: nops(select(t -> t < 2*n and isprime(t+1) and isprime(w/t + 1),  numtheory:-divisors(w)))
mathematica: f[n_] := Length@ Select[ Divisors[ 4n^2], # < 2n && PrimeQ[# + 1] && PrimeQ[ 4n^2/# + 1] &]; Array[f, 81] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Mar 30 2019 *)
program: (PARI) a(n) = {my(nb = 0, nn = 4*n^2); fordiv(nn, d, if (d == 2*n, break); if (isprime(d+1) && isprime(nn/d+1), nb++);); nb;} \\ _Michel Marcus_, Mar 06 2019
results.author: _Bernard Schott_, Mar 06 2019
